posts.name:
Mario Hernandez
Mario Hernandez
posts.content:
Let‚Äôs talk about something nobody‚Äôs really comparing: 


The cost of acquiring a customer in startups versus the cost of delivering a program in nonprofits.

On the surface, they‚Äôre miles apart.

One‚Äôs selling products or services; the other‚Äôs selling hope and impact.

But when you strip it down, they‚Äôre both chasing the same thing: sustainable growth.

So, why don‚Äôt they swap notes?

Startups: Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)

CAC measures what it costs to land a paying customer.

It‚Äôs the sum of marketing spend, sales expenses, and all those tools you‚Äôve subscribed to but forgot to cancel.

Common CAC metrics include:

Payback period: How long until that customer starts making you money?

Lifetime Value (LTV): Are they sticking around long enough to justify the upfront expense?

The goal?

Lower your CAC while increasing the LTV.

Simple formula. Hard execution.

Nonprofits: Program Delivery Costs

Nonprofits measure what it takes to deliver programs to beneficiaries.

It‚Äôs all about maximizing the dollars that go directly to impact versus admin or fundraising overhead.

Common nonprofit metrics include:

Cost per beneficiary: How much does it take to help one person?

Social ROI (SROI): What‚Äôs the measurable return on every dollar spent in terms of societal benefits?

The goal? Keep operational costs lean so more resources flow to the mission.

Where Startups and Nonprofits Overlap

CAC and program delivery costs are two sides of the same coin.

They both evaluate the efficiency of converting resources into meaningful results.

Startups could borrow from nonprofits by:

Tracking SROI equivalents: For impact-focused startups, how does your product directly create social value?

Measuring cost per outcome: If you‚Äôre claiming to solve a problem, break it down into tangible outcomes per dollar spent.

Nonprofits could learn from startups by:

Applying LTV frameworks: How long does a donor stay engaged? What‚Äôs their ‚Äúlifetime impact value‚Äù?

Using payback period metrics: For every dollar spent on acquiring donors, how quickly do you recoup it through donations or grants?


Startups and nonprofits are often stuck in their silos.

Startups chase growth at all costs, while nonprofits focus on doing more with less.

Both could grow faster (or make a bigger impact) by borrowing each other‚Äôs playbook.

If startups thought like nonprofits, they‚Äôd ask:

Is this growth creating meaningful change?

If nonprofits acted like startups, they‚Äôd ask:

Are we optimizing our ‚Äúcustomer journey‚Äù for donors and beneficiaries?


With purpose and impact,

Big Data üü• Data Science | Machine Learning | Deep Learning | Artificial Intelligence
posts.content:
True Trust: Actions Speak Louder Than Words
Trust in leadership isn't built on empty promises or lofty pronouncements. It's earned through consistent actions that demonstrate genuine faith in your team's abilities.

Micromanaging, despite well-intentioned words of trust, undermines this foundation. Constant oversight, excessive control, and a lack of autonomy stifle creativity, erode morale, and ultimately hinder team performance.

True trust is demonstrated through empowerment, delegation, and a genuine belief in your team's capabilities. It's about providing the necessary support and resources while allowing individuals the freedom to contribute their unique skills and perspectives.

By fostering a culture of trust and empowering my team, I've consistently witnessed increased engagement, improved performance, and a greater sense of ownership and pride in their work.

posts.name:
Dennis Olympios
Dennis Olympios
posts.content:
Is your next post the key to transforming your career? 

Picture this: one thoughtful post, seen by thousands, possibly millions. But it's not just the numbers that matter. A truly viral post can alter your professional path in unimaginable ways.

Here‚Äôs how:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Credibility Boost: Going viral positions you as a thought leader. It's beyond visibility‚Äîit's how people perceive you. Suddenly, you're the go-to expert.

2Ô∏è‚É£ New Opportunities: Decision-makers notice when your insights reach them. Get ready for job offers, speaking gigs, media features, and partnerships.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Global Reach: A viral post breaks barriers. Your insights can resonate across borders, lifting you onto the global stage.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Community Building: These posts spark dialogue and connections. They draw in followers who value your insights, laying the groundwork for lasting influence.

But remember, virality isn‚Äôt accidental. It requires a strategic blend of engaging content, a strong voice, and smart distribution.

The ROI of viral thought leadership is transformational.

So, what‚Äôs stopping you from being the expert your field needs?

 Share one insight that could elevate your personal brand!

comments.commentText:
Absolutely agree! A well-crafted post can do wonders for personal branding and career growth. It‚Äôs not just about going viral, but about building trust and delivering value consistently. The real power comes when you leverage that reach to foster connections and share your expertise.
We would like to add another point- Long-Term Impact: Going viral isn't just a one-time boost. It opens the door to sustained recognition, giving you a platform to influence and inspire over the long run.

posts.content: "Stop waiting for miracles. Life gives you only what you have the courage to demand."

comments.commentText:
Inspiring words!
Courage drives remarkable change.

Closed mouths don‚Äôt get fed. 

If you don‚Äôt ask, you don‚Äôt get. Asking means you believe you are worth it. It‚Äôs not just about saying words; it‚Äôs about being brave enough to try. 

Even if someone says no, you learn, you grow, and you get better. Every time you ask, you take a step forward. Don‚Äôt be scared.

Be bold and ask, because that‚Äôs how you open new doors in life.
Maheshwaran Tharali Chandrasekar Indeed we need to try to the best of our abilities to achieve our goals.Be fearless in pursuing anything which sets our soul on fire.

posts.name:
Depikka Siingh
Depikka Siingh
posts.content:
Dodging a bullet might just be my new superpower‚Äîthanks, L&T!

Working at L&T was once my dream.

Each time I passed their building, I pictured myself walking in as an employee.

I finally applied there back in 2016, got an interview, but was rejected‚Äî ironically the only interview I‚Äôve ever failed!

At the time, it stung, but today, I can‚Äôt help but feel immense gratitude for getting rejected there!

The recent comments by their chairman, advocating a 90-hour work week, left me stunned.

It‚Äôs 2024, not 1924!

Work-life balance isn‚Äôt a luxury‚Äîit‚Äôs a necessity.

Overworking doesn‚Äôt foster innovation; it leads to burnout.

To those navigating career choices: prioritize organizations that value your growth and well-being.

Your career should empower you, not exhaust you.

What are your thoughts on this?

comments.commentText: Your journey is a powerful reminder that sometimes setbacks lead us to better opportunities. Prioritizing our well-being over relentless hours is crucial in today's workplace. I'm glad you've found clarity in your path and are advocating for work-life balance, a necessary shift for sustainable growth and innovation.

This video reminded me of this quote I saw ages ago: 

"The bravest person is not the one who feels no fear, but the one who faces and overcomes it."

In business, there are many opportunities to be brave. Some people are afraid to take risks, but the bravest people are those who face their fears and overcome them.

Those who take risks already have a competitive advantage.

What's the bravest thing you've ever done in business?

Asking for a raise? Quitting a bad job? Flying on your own dime to see a client win a deal? Bigger???

posts.name:
Adam House Sr.
Adam House Sr.
posts.content:
How do we measure success on LinkedIn?

Have you ever stopped to think about what metrics really matter?

I‚Äôve tried it all:

Posting and ghosting.

Liking 100s of posts a day.

Leaving 100s of comments.

Spamming InMail.

Hollywood production level reels no one engages with

None of it worked like I wanted it to.


But since meetingand following his process, my LinkedIn stats look like Mount Everest.

And it‚Äôs not just me‚Äîothers in the¬Æ community are seeing the same growth.

Here‚Äôs what we‚Äôve learned:

LinkedIn is like a cocktail party.

Would you run around having one-second conversations with 100 people?

Or would you rather have 5 meaningful conversations that actually matter?

When you meet someone, you don‚Äôt hand them your business card immediately.
You build a relationship first.

While LinkedIn might be free, you‚Äôre paying with your time and missed opportunities.

The key? Be intentional, consistent, and focused on what truly matters.

Brick by Brick¬Æ, success is built with purpose.

Keep Building,

comments.commentText: I have had my my mind changed about LinkedIn in the last 12 months. I would rather get to know 5 people than casually meet 100. Likes on a post without dialogue are the worst thing for LinkedIn. It‚Äôs what everyone is chasing here, and quite wrongly.
Michael Hopefully, many will follow the trend but it is unlikely.

Adam it feels amazing when you have under 1k impressions on a post but 100 likes and 100 comments. That‚Äôs a real network. It may not grow like weeds but it‚Äôs ok, it means you‚Äôve built a community that likes what you have to say and shows up for you. It‚Äôs much easier to get followers and likes.

posts.name:
Codie Petersen
Codie Petersen
posts.content:
The people using AI to make LinkedIn posts or comments are so lazy in their analysis of the content they neither recognize nor care to remove the "‚Äî" character (em dash it is apparently called).

If they are that lazy, they don't deserve the 0.5 seconds it takes to like and share. Your interaction is more valuable than their content, because their content is just an averaged out regurgitation of a point of view that was so represented in the public body of knowledge that it is likely the first thing an AI spat out for them.

So, if you see that em dash, don't even waste your time reading the rest. To be honest, I'm just blocking people now. And I'm unfollowing people who are highly susceptible to liking or sharing such content.

There is a saying "you are the average of the 5 people you hang around the most", well, pretty soon it's not going to be that hard to be above average.

posts.name:

posts.content:
An idea which undoubtedly changed my life 

And will change yours too

For years, I thought success was about doing more.

More goals. More tasks. More effort. More everything.

Yet after a particularly trying year, one idea changed everything for me:

ùóôùóºùó∞ùòÇùòÄ ùó∞ùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÅùó≤ùòÄ ùó≥ùóøùó≤ùó≤ùó±ùóºùó∫.

When I stopped trying to juggle everything,

I found clarity, momentum, and the freedom to focus on what truly mattered.

Here‚Äôs what shifted:
1. ùóú ùóπùó≤ùóÆùóøùóªùó≤ùó± ùòÅùóº ùòÄùóÆùòÜ ùóªùóº.
‚Ü≥ Not every opportunity deserves your attention.
 Saying yes to everything only keeps you stuck.

2. ùóú ùóΩùóøùó∂ùóºùóøùó∂ùòÅùó∂ùòáùó≤ùó± ùòÄùòÜùòÄùòÅùó≤ùó∫ùòÄ ùóºùòÉùó≤ùóø ùòÄùóΩùóºùóªùòÅùóÆùóªùó≤ùó∂ùòÅùòÜ.
‚Ü≥ Working smarter‚Äînot harder
 This meant doubling down on the few things that moved the needle.

3. ùóú ùó∞ùóøùó≤ùóÆùòÅùó≤ùó± ùòÄùóΩùóÆùó∞ùó≤ ùó≥ùóºùóø ùòÑùóµùóÆùòÅ ùó∫ùóÆùòÅùòÅùó≤ùóøùòÄ.
‚Ü≥ By clearing out the noise, I made room for meaningful daily work.
 I prioritized family, health, friends, and personal growth.

The moment I embraced the idea that Focus creates freedom, everything changed.

I stopped spinning my wheels, juggling countless plates, and started making real progress.

If you‚Äôre feeling stuck or overwhelmed, let me ask you this:

What‚Äôs one area of your life where focus could make the biggest impact?

Let me know in the comments‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts ‚¨áÔ∏è

The freedom to move forward is waiting on the other side of clarity.
